Graphical abstract Titanosilicate supports of different pore sizes were synthesized by a surfactant-free templating method. Cobalt was loaded by incipient wetness impregnation on the synthesized supports and commercial γ-Al2O3. The Fischer–Tropsch activities of the catalysts were studied with and without prior calcination in a fixed bed reactor at 220 °C, 1.83 MPa and 2000 mLsyngas/mLcatalyst/h after in situ reduction. XANES analysis of the catalysts revealed that after reduction, a greater fraction of the loaded cobalt had been reduced in the calcined catalyst (74 %) compared to the uncalcined catalyst (58 %). Activity studies revealed that the CO conversion and C5+ selectivities of the catalysts with medium pore titanosilicate supports was higher (80 % conversion, 81–85 % selectivity) than the CO conversion by Co/γ-Al2O3 (77 % conversion, 76 % selectivity). Calcination in air increased the liquid product selectivity of all the catalysts towards the diesel fraction from 21–24 % to 25–32 %. Abbreviations CAM calcined medium pore catalyst CAN calcined narrow pore catalyst CAW calcined wide pore catalyst CLS Canadian Light Source CTY cobalt-time yield (moles of CO reacted per gram of cobalt per second) SXRMB Soft X-Ray Microcharacterization Beamline TOS time-on-stream (h) UCM uncalcined medium pore catalyst UCN uncalcined narrow pore catalyst UCW uncalcined wide pore catalyst XANES X-ray absorption near edge structure Keywords Fischer–Tropsch Co catalyst Mesoporous titanosilicate XANES 1 Introduction Supported cobalt catalysts remain one of the most researched materials for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis due to their high activity and selectivity for long-chain linear hydrocarbons. For optimal usage of the active metal, it is imperative that the cobalt be dispersed on supports possessing high surface area [1]. While it is desirable to have highly dispersed and easily reducible catalysts, it is often observed that higher dispersions result in lower reducibility due to the interactions between the active metal and support. Such interactions render a fraction of the cobalt chemically inactive. Earlier investigations by Iglesia demonstrated that the Fischer–Tropsch activity of cobalt particles larger than 9 nm was independent of cobalt particle size [2]. Further investigations by den Breejen et al. established that cobalt particles smaller than 6 nm had high selectivity towards methane due to higher coverage of hydrogen on the edges of the particles which effectively reduced the CHx residence time and coverage [3]. Therefore, a Co particle range of 8−15 nm is often used to ensure an optimal usage of cobalt for Fischer–Tropsch catalysts [4]. The pore size of a support affects the surface properties of the catalyst and dictates the size of the active metal clusters that can be formed. Rytter and Holmen synthesized cobalt catalysts supported on different alumina supports and reported the formation of cobalt oxide particles larger than the pore sizes of the supports due to complex entanglement of the active metal with the support [4]. They also reported that the C5+ selectivity of cobalt catalysts supported on titania and α-alumina were higher than the C5+ selectivity of γ- and θ-alumina. Bartolini et al. studied the effects of textural properties of three different SBA-15 supports on the performance of cobalt-catalysts towards Fischer–Tropsch synthesis [5] and reported a wider particle size distribution in larger pore catalyst. Investigations by Rahmati et al. revealed that the use of silica-alumina with a bimodal pore distribution helped to accommodate Co crystals in the catalysts without blocking the pores [6]. Abrokwah et al. studied the effects of titania support on the Fischer–Tropsch activities of iron, cobalt and ruthenium using a silicon microchannel microreactor and discovered that cobalt was most active at 220 °C when supported on anatase phase of titania [7]. The preparation of supported cobalt catalysts involves the impregnation and subsequent thermal treatment to decompose a cobalt-source on the surface of the support. The method of impregnation and subsequent thermal treatments will influence the dispersion of the cobalt on the end catalysts. The atmosphere in which the cobalt precursor decomposes can be critical for the transformation of cobalt nitrate into its oxide. Wolters et al. investigated the decomposition of supported first row transition metal nitrates in a nitric oxide-rich environment and reported that a higher dispersion and narrower particle size distribution of cobalt oxide can be obtained by introducing small quantities of NO gas while calcining [8]. In related research, Khassin et al. reported that the presence of 3 % NO in flowing argon increased the formation of cobalt aluminates but did not have a pronounced effect on the Fischer–Tropsch activities of cobalt-based catalysts supported on alumina [9]. The authors indicated that the catalysts precalcined in the presence of NO produced less methane and were selective to olefins compared to the catalysts calcined in an inert atmosphere. However, Borg et al. reported that calcination at a low temperature ensured high dispersion of cobalt; whereas, the composition and flowrate of a gas over the catalyst during calcination had no strong effect on either the dispersion or the Fischer–Tropsch activity of the catalysts [10]. Sun et al. investigated the Fischer–Tropsch activities of mesoporous zeolite-supported cobalt-based catalysts calcined in different atmospheres and reported that the calcination of catalysts in stagnant air resulted in the highest activity towards FTS. However, they reported that the use of a flowing gas stream suppressed the redistribution of cobalt oxides and resulted in a more reducible catalyst [11]. In our previous work, various metallosilicates were synthesized to study the effects of heteroatoms in a silica matrix by using a surfactant-free one-pot synthesis technique [12]. The templating method used to produce a silicious material TUD-1 (Technische Universiteit Delft-1) which possesses foam-like network, was modified and adopted to synthesize the metallosilicates. Autogenous pressure of about 50 psig (0.3 MPa) was used to ensure uniform pores of similar dimensions in all the previously synthesized supports. It was discovered that catalysts synthesized with titanosilicates (TiTUD-1) as supports had the highest activity among the tested materials. While various modifications have been made to silica in the form of post-synthesis addition of structural promoters, no attention has been received for titanosilicates synthesized by one-pot procedures or the effect of pore size of such supports on the Fischer–Tropsch activities of their resulting catalysts. In this work, the effects of pore size of the titanosilicate support on the Fischer–Tropsch activity of the catalysts were investigated and their activities were compared with that of cobalt loaded on commercial γ-alumina (γ-Al2O3). The effect of calcination atmosphere (N2 or air) was also tested to determine whether the presence of oxygen affected the thermal decomposition profiles of the catalysts. The activities of all the catalysts were tested in a fixed bed reactor under industrially relevant conditions (220 °C, 1.83 MPa and 2000 mLsyngas/mLcatalyst/h). All the synthesized catalysts exhibited higher activity than Co/γ-Al2O3. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), commercial γ-alumina and cobalt nitrate hexahydrate were purchased from Alfa Aesar (Tewksbury, United States). 35 wt.% tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH) and titanium n-butoxide were procured from Aldrich (St. Louis, United States). Triethanolamine (TEA) was procured from Anachemia (Mississauga, Canada). All gasses were purchased from Praxair (Canada). The chemicals were used without further processing. 2.2 Support synthesis The procedure used to synthesize the support has been previously reported by Kamath et al. [12]. In a typical synthesis to produce 10 g of support, 30.6 g of TEOS, 5 g of titanium n-butoxide and 6.6 g of the structure directing agent were mixed to obtain a clear yellow solution. To this solution, a dilute aqueous solution of TEAOH was added dropwise to initiate hydrolysis. The resulting solution having a composition of 1SiO2:0.1TiO2:0.3TEA:0.1TEAOH:11H2O was aged at room temperature for 24 h. The gel obtained at the end of the aging period was dried and hydrothermally treated at 200 °C. The hydrothermal pressure was adjusted to 30 psig, 50 psig and 150 psig (0.2 MPa, 0.3 MPa and 1 MPa) using nitrogen to tailor the pore size of the support [13]. The gel obtained was calcined under static air at 700 °C for 10 h with a ramp rate of 1 °C/min. The crystalline granular solids obtained were ground using a mortar and pestle. 2.3 Catalyst synthesis The supports were impregnated with cobalt nitrate hexahydrate using the incipient wetness impregnation method. For a nominal loading of 15 wt.% Co, earlier investigations had shown the resulting catalysts to possess a cobalt loading of 13−14 wt.% Co [12]. All the catalysts were dried at 65 °C under vacuum overnight. Half of all the catalysts were calcined under static air at 400 °C and labelled as calcined (CA) catalysts. The uncalcined catalysts (UC) were labelled and stored. Gamma alumina (γ-Al2O3), an industrial support was also loaded with cobalt nitrate and calcined at 400 °C for comparison. 2.4 Catalyst passivation The decomposition of cobalt nitrate was observed to start at around 98 °C and the decomposition was independent of the presence of atmospheric oxygen (Fig. 1 ). Since some of the characterization techniques would require the sample to be heated above 100 °C for analysis, all the uncalcined catalysts were passivated prior to analysis. To passivate the catalyst, 1 g of each uncalcined catalyst was heated to 400 °C for 18 h and cooled to room temperature under flowing hydrogen inside a fixed bed reactor. The reactor was purged with argon and 1 mol.% oxygen in argon was passed through the catalysts at room temperature for 4 h. This treatment was expected to create a thin layer of Co3O4 over the cobalt crystallites rendering the catalyst passive to further oxidation in air. These catalysts were termed as passivated catalysts and used to determine the approximate textural properties of the uncalcined catalysts in the reactor during the time-on-stream studies. 2.5 Characterization techniques 2.5.1 Thermogravimetric analysis Prior to calcination, the decomposition of cobalt nitrate was studied by collecting the weight loss profile of the uncalcined catalysts using a PerkinElmer Pyris Diamond TG/DTA instrument. 20 mg of each dry sample was heated at 10 °C/min from 30 to 800 °C and the change in weight was recorded in intervals of 0.5 s. The sample cavity was purged with either nitrogen or air with a flowrate of 50 mL/min. 2.5.2 Nitrogen physisorption Nitrogen isotherms of the samples were obtained using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area analyser at liquid nitrogen temperatures. About 200 mg of the supports, calcined catalysts and passivated samples were degassed at 150 °C at 0.5 mm Hg (66.7 Pa) pressure for 120 min prior to analysis. The surface area of the samples was calculated using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method and the pore size and pore volume were computed using the Barret–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) model. 2.5.3 X-ray diffraction The powder X-ray diffractograms of the calcined and passivated catalysts were obtained on a D8 Advance Powder Diffractometer equipped with GE monochromator. The diffractograms were collected with a scan rate of 2°/min between 2θ values of 10° to 90°. 2.5.4 Temperature programmed reduction The reduction behaviour of the calcined and uncalcined samples were determined using a Micromeritics AutoChem HP instrument. About 40 mg of the samples were loaded into a stainless-steel U-shaped tube and the tube was purged with helium. The samples were heated from 100 °C to 800 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min and a 50 mL/min flow of 10 %H2 in Argon was used to reduce the samples. 2.5.5 Hydrogen chemisorption The active metal dispersion on each catalyst was estimated using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. About 100 mg of the calcined and passivated samples were loaded into a U-shaped sample holder and reduced at 400 °C using hydrogen gas for 150 min. The sample tube was evacuated to 1.3 × 10−5 Pa and cooled to 35 °C. The hydrogen adsorption isotherms were collected at this temperature by assuming a H:Co adsorption stoichiometry of 1:1. 2.5.6 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy The XPS measurements were collected at the Saskatchewan Structural Sciences Centre, Saskatoon using a Kratos AXIS Supra system (Manchester, UK). For the analysis, a monochromated Al K-α source (1486.6 eV) was used with a spot size of 300 × 700 μm. An accelerating voltage of 15 keV and an emission current of 15 mA were used for the analysis. The survey spectra was collected in the binding energy range of −5 to 1200 eV in steps of 1 eV with a pass energy of 160 eV. High resolution scans of the cobalt 2p edge were collected with a pass energy of 20 eV in steps of 0.1 eV. 2.5.7 X-ray absorption spectroscopy The XAS spectra of the reduced samples were collected at the Soft X-Ray Microcharacterization Beamline (SXRMB) at the Canadian Light Source, Saskatoon. SXRMB is a bending-magnet based beamline and it covers a photon energy range of 2–10 keV. Prior to analysis, the samples were reduced using a six-hole shooter set up at 400 °C for 18 h with a hydrogen flow of 30 mL/min [14]. The samples were dispersed over double-sided conductive carbon tape inside a glove box to prevent oxidation of the samples. Then Co K-edge absorption spectra were collected in Fluorescence Yield (FLY) using a 7-element Silicon Drift Detector. The reduction extent of cobalt in the catalysts were determined by comparing the spectra of the reduced samples with the spectra of metallic cobalt foil and cobalt (II and III) oxide standards using the linear combination fitting function in the ATHENA software package [15]. 2.6 Activity study Fischer–Tropsch reactions were carried out in a 1 cm ID fixed-bed reactor using industrially relevant conditions (220 °C, 1.83 MPa and 2000 mLsyngas/mLcatalyst/h). The reactor was enclosed in a PID-controlled furnace and connected to Brooks mass flow controllers. To determine their activity, one gram of the catalyst was diluted with seven grams of inert silica carbide and loaded into the reactor. Diluting the catalyst with an inert material ensures isothermal behaviour and suppresses undesirable effects like bypassing [16]. The catalysts were reduced in situ at 400 °C under ultrahigh purity hydrogen flow of 30 mL/min for 18 h. The reactor was then cooled to 180 °C and heated to reaction condition. The reactor was pressurised to 1.83 MPa (250 psig) using helium. A premixed syngas with a H2:CO ratio of 2:1 with 10 % argon as tie component was passed through the reactor with a flowrate of 2000 mLsyngas/mLcatalyst/h. The reactants from the reactor were passed through two product collection receptacles maintained at 100 °C and 0 °C, respectively. The exhaust gasses were analyzed using a Shimadzu-2014 GC to estimate the CO conversion and hydrocarbon selectivities. The liquid products were collected after ∼100 h of TOS and analyzed by a Varian CP-3800 GC. The Fischer–Tropsch activity was reported in moles of carbon monoxide converted per gram of cobalt loaded in the reactor per second (cobalt-time yield, CTY) [17]. The α-value was estimated for the range of C8–C18 and the weight fractions of gasoline (C5–C12), diesel (C13–C20) and waxes (C20+) in the liquid product were also reported. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Material characterization The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution were collected to confirm the formation of mesopores in the support (Fig. 2 ). It was noticed that all the supports exhibited type-IV isotherm indicating the presence of mesopores. The textural properties of the supports are presented in Table 1 . It was observed that the synthesis gels treated at 30, 50 and 150 psig resulted in titanosilicate supports with pore sizes of 5.5, 8.9 and 24.1 nm, respectively. Therefore, the three supports are henceforth named Narrow (N), Medium (M) and Wide (W), respectively. The γ-Al2O3 exhibited a pore size of 6.4 nm. Furthermore, it was observed that γ-Al2O3, narrow and medium supports exhibited H1 type hysteresis indicating uniform pores with a narrow pore size distribution while the wide pore support exhibited a H3 type hysteresis which indicates the presence of slit-like pores with a broad pore-size distribution. These observations were confirmed by the pore size distribution profile (Fig. 2) which indicated that the median pore size of the γ-Al2O3, narrow and medium supports coincided with the average pore sizes calculated by the BET method. However, it was observed that the pore size distribution of the wide support was broad, and the median pore size of the support appeared to be ∼45 nm as compared to the average pore size of 24.1 nm estimated by the BET method. The supports exhibited high surface areas in the range of 200–670 m2/g and had pore volumes in the range of 0.7–1.5 mL/g (Table 1). This information was used to calculate the quantity of aqueous cobalt nitrate solution needed to load 15 wt.% Co on the supports by incipient wetness impregnation [18]. The decomposition of cobalt nitrate was studied to establish the conditions for the drying of uncalcined samples (Fig. 1). Cobalt nitrate was heated in a cavity that was purged with nitrogen and with air. In both scenarios, the onset temperature for the decomposition of cobalt nitrate was observed to be around 98 °C and the weight of the remaining sample remained constant after around 275 °C. This suggested that the conversion of Co(NO3)2·6H2O to Co3O4 was solely dependent on the temperature and not on the drying/calcination atmosphere. Therefore, during the synthesis of the catalysts, the supports were dried at 65 °C under vacuum in a vacuum oven to prevent the decomposition of the loaded cobalt nitrate. The decomposition profiles of the dried catalysts were studied to investigate their weight-loss with heat. It was noticed that the dried catalysts exhibited a profile similar to the decomposition of pure cobalt nitrate with an onset temperature of about 98 °C in all cases. However, the weight-loss stopped at about 225 °C for all the catalyst samples. Furthermore, the decomposition of the Co/Medium was studied under nitrogen and air to ascertain that the chemical decomposition of the precursor was independent of the calcination atmosphere even in the presence of a support. This hypothesis was validated, and the weight loss profile of the catalyst remained identical in both nitrogen and oxygen containing atmospheres. Similar results were reported by Borg et al. [10] who studied the effects of calcination flowrate and gas composition on the decomposition of cobalt supported on γ-Al2O3 and their subsequent Fischer–Tropsch activities. These researchers reported that above 200 °C, the calcination atmosphere did not have any noticeable effect on the performance of the catalyst. The dried catalysts were divided into two fractions and one fraction was calcined in static air at 400 °C. The calcined (CA) catalysts were characterized in their oxide state whereas the uncalcined catalysts (UC) were passivated prior to characterization. The textural properties of the calcined and passivated samples are provided in Table 2 . All the catalysts exhibited a decrease in surface area after impregnation. With the assumption that the cobalt crystals do not contribute to the surface area of the catalyst, a cobalt loading of 15 wt.% should reduce the effective surface area of the catalyst by 20–25 % as compared to their corresponding supports and this trend was observed in the synthesized catalysts [15]. A slight increase was observed in the pore diameters of the catalysts as compared to their supports. As the solvent in the precursor solution evaporates during drying, the cobalt nitrate solution gets more concentrated and gets drawn into the smaller pores due to capillary action. When the solution reaches saturation concentration, the precursor starts to crystallize in these smaller pores, effectively blocking them off. Therefore, the average pore sizes of the catalysts increase after the impregnation of cobalt [12,18]. The BET isotherms of the catalysts (Supplementary information Figs. S1 and S2) indicate that the isotherms of the calcined and passivated catalysts are identical to the isotherms of the supports. This implies that the pore structure of the support is retained after impregnation, drying and calcination. The formation of the catalyst was verified by collecting the X-ray diffractograms of the calcined and passivated catalysts shown in Fig. 3 . The X-ray diffractograms of the TiTUD-1 support and Co3O4 standards are also included for reference. The presence of peaks at 2θ values of 20°, 31°, 37°, 39°, 45°, 56°, 60°, 65° and 78° indicated the formation of Co3O4 spinels. The cobalt crystal sizes calculated using the Scherrer equation indicated that the crystal sizes were in the range of 8−15 nm (Table 2) which is considered to be optimal for Ficher-Tropsch synthesis [2,3]. Some residual structure was observed from the TiTUD-1 support in the catalysts which is due to the extraframework titania [19,7]. It was observed that the UCW catalyst exhibited peaks at 44°, 47° and 75° which correspond to the presence of metallic cobalt. Khodakov et al. proposed the formation of amorphous cobalt oxide layer over the surface of bulk cobalt metal particles, which renders it immune to further oxidation since the oxide layer would considerably slow down the oxidation of cobalt [17]. XRD analysis is insensitive to this amorphous cobalt oxide and thus, the cobalt particle size calculated from XRD (Table 2) would be considerably smaller than the actual size. Furthermore, cobalt oxide crystals did not display a strong contrast against their supports in micrographs and thus XRD was the primary technique used to determine particle size. Since dispersion decreases with particle size, it would be expected that the catalyst possessing the largest particle size would have the lowest dispersion. This hypothesis is further supported by the dispersion exhibited by UCW, which was calculated by hydrogen chemisorption (Table 2) and is the lowest among the catalysts tested. The interaction of the cobalt with the support also affected the dispersion. The XPS spectra of the calcined (CAM), uncalcined (UCM) and passivated catalysts are presented in Fig. 4 . Cobalt 2p spectra exhibits spin orbital splitting accompanied by satellite features, which indicate the presence of isolated Co2+ species dispersed in the support in the form of cobalt metal oxides [5,20]. Since both peaks convey the same information, only the 2p3/2 peak was considered for fitting. The spectra of the uncalcined catalyst indicated that cobalt nitrate was the principal cobalt compound in the uncalcined sample. The ratio of intensities of Co3O4 spinel peaks to the intensity of the satellite feature can be used to compare the degree of interactions between the cobalt and support in different catalysts [12]. The I C o 2 p 3 / 2 /Isatellite values of the different catalysts are given in Table 3 . The greater the degree of interaction between the cobalt and the metal, lower is the value of I C o 2 p 3 / 2 /Isatellite. The value of I C o 2 p 3 / 2 /Isatellite for Co/γ-Al2O3 was lowest among the catalysts tested implying that the interaction between the support and cobalt was strongest in that catalyst [9]. However, the value of I C o 2 p 3 / 2 /Isatellite was lower for passivated catalysts compared to calcined catalysts. Since the passivated catalysts were heated in a reducing environment, the hydrogen might have scavenged the oxygen radicals as they were formed preventing the active metal from agglomerating. While this improves the dispersion of the cobalt oxide crystallites, it also promotes the formation of irreducible cobalt metal oxides. Therefore, the cobalt is rendered chemically inert, and thus, the passivated catalysts have a lower dispersion of cobalt compared to the calcined catalysts. The reduction profiles of the catalysts were studied with temperature programmed reduction and are shown in Fig. 5 . The calcined catalysts exhibited a bimodal peak that corresponded to the reduction of Co3O4 → CoO followed by CoO → Co. The areas of the two peaks were in the ratio of 1:3 which corresponds to the relative concentrations of oxygen removed during each of the respective transitions [6]. The uncalcined catalysts had an additional peak between 150−200 °C that corresponded to the decomposition of cobalt nitrate precursor [8]. It was observed that all the titanosilicate supported catalysts exhibited lower reduction temperatures for the CoO → Co transition compared to Co/γ-Al2O3 (490 °C). Additionally, it was observed that the transition of Co3O4 → CoO was at a lower temperature in the uncalcined catalysts at 215 °C compared to the calcined catalysts at 250 °C. However, the reduction temperature of CoO → Co was unaffected by the calcination step. The temperature programmed reduction technique uses the composition of the analysis gas as a proxy to study the oxidation states of the catalyst, the peaks produced have to be interpreted with a certain degree of ambiguity. Therefore, X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) analysis was used to compare the degree of reduction of the catalysts under the conditions used for in situ reduction prior to reaction. The two catalysts supported on medium pore titanosilicate with and without calcination were loaded into a six-hole shooter set up with the catalysts loaded on commercial γ-Al2O3 and a catalyst supported on mesoporous silica (TUD-1) from an earlier investigation [12] for comparison. The catalysts were reduced at 400 °C under hydrogen flow of 30 mL/min for 18 h and transferred onto conductive double-sided carbon tape in an argon-filled glove box at the SXRMB beamline of the Canadian Light Source. The obtained spectra are presented in Fig. 6 . The analysis of XANES spectra gives a lot of useful information about the oxidation states of the cobalt in the sample. A unit cell of Co3O4 crystal possesses two atoms of Co in the +3 oxidation state and one atom in the +2 oxidation state whereas all unit cells of CoO only contain atoms in the +2 oxidation state. The atoms in +3 oxidation state possess tetrahedral symmetry and contribute to a pre-edge feature in the spectra which corresponds to 1s → 3d transitions. These transitions are forbidden for the cobalt atoms possessing +2 oxidation states since they possess an octahedral symmetry and therefore, the intensity of the pre-edge decreases during the Co3O4 → CoO transition. Furthermore, the intensity of the white line peak increases and the energy position of the adsorption peak shifts to higher energy levels with increasing oxidation state of the cobalt [21,22]. The software Athena from the package Demeter was used to analyse the obtained spectra using linear combination fitting was from 7703.93 to 7753.93 eV to determine the oxidation states of the catalysts after reduction. The fitting parameters used in this work are presented in Table 3 and the spectra of the catalysts are presented with the model fit as well as the weighted components in the supplementary information (Figs. S3–S6). It can be observed that the calcined catalyst supported on titanosilicate had the highest percentage of metallic cobalt after reduction (74 %). However, it also had a higher percentage of Co3O4 compared to the catalyst supported on silica. The calcined Co/TiTUD-1 also had the lowest concentration of CoO among the catalysts tested. It has been proposed by Saib et al. that the presence of CoO is crucial for the hydrogenation of carbon monoxide [23]. This explains the high initial activity exhibited by silica supported catalysts as reported by Kamath et al. However, investigations by Jacobs et al. revealed that the ratio of Co/CoO reaches equilibrium after about 20 h of TOS due to the oxidation of Co by the dissociation of CO [22]. The lower percentage of metallic cobalt in the uncalcined catalyst and the higher percentage of CoO further support the hypothesis that the loaded cobalt has higher interactions with the support as speculated from the XPS results. It is also interesting to note that the Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst had the lowest percentage of metallic cobalt at 43 %. While this is in accordance with the observations from the TPR spectra which showed the reduction temperature of the catalyst to be at 490 °C, the results of the H2 chemisorption- which reduced the catalysts at 400 °C under hydrogen prior to analysis- showed the dispersion of Co/γ-Al2O3 to be comparable to the dispersion of CAN. Therefore, all catalysts were reduced in situ at 400 °C under a hydrogen flowrate of 30 mL/min prior to the time-on-stream study. 3.2 Activity study The time-on-stream activity of the catalysts was monitored for 100 h and the activity of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 . It was noticed that the activity of the catalysts dropped a little at the beginning and remained stable after 20 h of TOS. The absence of a declining trend in activity even after 100 h of TOS indicates that the cobalt crystals were firmly anchored to their supports due to the interactions of the cobalt with the alumina and titania in the supports. The medium pore catalysts (CAM, UCM) exhibited a higher activity compared to their respective narrow (CAN, UCN) and wide (CAW, UCW) pore catalysts for both calcined and uncalcined materials. Since the large pore catalysts (22.6–23.5 nm) had larger Co particles (12.5–13.8 nm), the effective surface area of the cobalt was reduced, thus reducing the activity. The CO conversion and product selectivities of the catalysts are presented in Table 4 . Although in practice there is some overlap between hydrocarbons in the gasoline and diesel range, we have reported C5–C12 compounds as gasoline and C13–C20 compounds as diesel. However, since some flash-gasses escape during liquid product collection, the chain growth probability (α-value) was calculated for C8–C18 compounds. It can be noticed that the calcined catalysts supported on TiTUD-1 produced waxes (C21+ compounds) and had a higher selectivity for the diesel fraction of the liquid products. This behaviour can be ascribed to the larger cobalt particle sizes and greater metal dispersion in the calcined catalysts compared to the uncalcined catalysts. These two parameters suggest greater cobalt site density in the calcined catalysts which are known to increase higher hydrocarbon selectivity [3]. Additionally, it was also observed that the chain growth factor α increased with increasing pore size [5]. The activities of the catalysts are reported in cobalt-time yield to normalise the effect of differing densities of the catalysts. Comparing the activity of the synthesized catalysts with the Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, it can be noticed that the cobalt-time yield, α-value and C5+ selectivities for all the synthesized catalysts were higher. It was also observed that the selectivity towards undesirable by-products like CO2 and CH4 were lower for the synthesized catalysts. It can be speculated that the lower activity of the Co/γ-Al2O3 might be due to the lower extent of reduction of the cobalt in this catalyst due to strong support-metal interaction with the γ-alumina [9]. However, the results of the hydrogen chemisorption (Table 2) indicate that the dispersion of cobalt on γ-alumina is comparable to the dispersion of cobalt over the titanosilicate supports and thus, it can be concluded that the interactions of cobalt with titania in the synthesized titanosilicate supports promotes their Fischer–Tropsch activity. It was also observed that the activities of the wide pore catalysts were similar with and without calcination. This can be attributed to the larger cobalt particle diameters in the catalysts which are easier to reduce. However, the uncalcined catalyst (UCW, Fig. 8 ) had lower C5+ selectivity and lower α-value than the calcined catalyst; and, did not produce waxes. Since it was established that the cobalt in uncalcined catalysts interacts more strongly with the support than calcined catalysts, titania in the support might migrate over the surface of the cobalt catalysts and impede chain growth [4]. Such a reduction in selectivity for C5+ hydrocarbons is also seen in the catalyst supported on uncalcined narrow titanosilicate (UCN). Although UCN and its calcined analogue CAN both possess similar pore morphologies as indicated by the nitrogen physisorption results, it can be noticed that the cobalt crystallite sizes are larger in UCN while the dispersion is lower. This indicates that while the capillary forces draw the cobalt precursors into smaller pores and pore openings, the strong interaction between cobalt and the titania forms a considerable quantity of irreducible cobalt titanates which are inactive for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis. 4 Conclusions Three titanosilicate supports with different pore sizes were synthesized by altering the conditions of a surfactant-free hydrothermal synthesis process. Catalysts were prepared by loading 15 wt.% Co and drying under vacuum. Nitrogen physisorption analysis revealed that the addition of a calcination step increased the surface area of the catalysts by 5–25 m2/g. Investigation of the extent of reduction by XANES analysis revealed that under similar reduction conditions (400 °C, 30 mL/min of hydrogen flow for 18 h), calcined Co/TiTUD-1 (cobalt supported on titanosilicate support) catalysts had a higher fraction of metallic cobalt (74 %) compared to Co/γ-Al2O3, Co/TUD-1 (cobalt supported on silica support) and uncalcined Co/TiTUD-1. The inclusion of a calcination step increased the temperature for the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO (215 °C–250 °C); however, it had no effect on the reduction temperature of CoO to Co (340 °C). Time-on-stream studies revealed that the catalysts remained stable after 20 h of TOS for up to 100 h of TOS. The catalysts supported on wide pore titanosilicates showed some decline in activity (7.9−5.8 × 10−5 molCO/gCo/s) with time and this decline was similar in both the calcined and uncalcined catalysts. The medium pore supported catalysts exhibited a higher activity compared to the narrow pore catalyst and both sets of catalysts retained their activity for 100 h of TOS. The synthesized catalysts exhibited a higher activity (4.5–8.4 × 10−5 molCO/gCo/s) compared to the activity of Co/γ-Al2O3 (4.8 × 10−5 molCO/gCo/s). The synthesized catalysts also exhibited higher α-value for C8-C18 (0.79−0.92) compared to Co/γ-Al2O3. α-values increased with pore diameter, and the calcined catalysts had higher α-values (0.87−0.92) compared to the uncalcined catalysts (0.79−0.81). From the XPS analysis it was discovered that the cobalt crystals in uncalcined catalysts have a higher interaction with the support than those in the calcined catalysts. However, both the metal-support interactions of the titanosilicate supported catalysts are lower in comparison to the metal-support interaction of Co/γ-Al2O3. Thus, it can be concluded that the interaction between the cobalt and titania in the catalyst is beneficial for the Fischer–Tropsch activities of the titanosilicate supported catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Titanosilicate supports of different pore sizes were synthesized by a surfactant-free templating method. Cobalt was loaded by incipient wetness impregnation on the synthesized supports and commercial γ-Al2O3. The Fischer–Tropsch activities of the catalysts were studied with and without prior calcination in a fixed bed reactor at 220 °C, 1.83 MPa and 2000 mLsyngas/mLcatalyst/h after in situ reduction. XANES analysis of the catalysts revealed that after reduction, a greater fraction of the loaded cobalt had been reduced in the calcined catalyst (74 %) compared to the uncalcined catalyst (58 %). Activity studies revealed that the CO conversion and C5+ selectivities of the catalysts with medium pore titanosilicate supports was higher (80 % conversion, 81–85 % selectivity) than the CO conversion by Co/γ-Al2O3 (77 % conversion, 76 % selectivity). Calcination in air increased the liquid product selectivity of all the catalysts towards the diesel fraction from 21–24 % to 25–32 %.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of calcination on physico-chemical properties and Ficher–Tropsch activity of titanosilicate supported cobalt catalysts with different pore sizes
